Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Advanced X-Ray Diffraction System to Support Interdisciplinary Research and Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical: This NSF-Major Research Instrumentation award for an advanced X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) system, with materials structure and size analysis capabilities down to atomic scale, fulfills critical research and educational needs at Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI). The XRD system enhances IUPUI's shared instrumentation profile, and supports faculty and students across many schools and departments by providing capabilities for a range of interdisciplinary scientific discovery and workforce training. This instrumentation significantly broadens investigator ability to characterize the properties of solid materials, especially of nanoscale-size, for fundamental research projects that provide the basis for applications in Earth Sciences (ore and energy deposits, water quality, and minerals impacts on human health), Nanotechnology (new materials development for energy, industry, and biomedical applications), and Biophysical research (biological membrane function in biomaterials including amino acids, detergents, and pharmaceuticals). Supporting the development of the nation's 21st century science and engineering workforce, this instrumentation is used in both key coursework across several disciplines and is central to educational outreach programs for K-12 students and teachers across Indiana and the U.S.

Technical: Characterization of solid state material structure and size is a critical research need for an array of IUPUI researchers. The advanced X-ray diffraction (XRD) system supports growing research efforts in many fields by providing high resolution and high throughput diffraction data, the ability to acquire data on samples contained in a controlled temperature and atmospheric chamber, and the capability of gathering small angle X-ray scattering information for both solids and thin films. These advances make quantification of many nanoscale material properties possible, support 22 major ongoing projects and open new avenues of interdisciplinary research for at least 20 faculty and their associated research groups at IUPUI. Current faculty research areas include: Earth Sciences, understanding mineral distribution and reactivity linked to human health and characterizing mineral transformations key to water quality, ore and energy materials, evolution of earth and life through time, and structural geology in a range of temperature, pressure, and atmospheric conditions; Energy Storage and Photovoltaic Technologies, for advanced energy applications; Nanomaterials, for industrial and biomaterials applications (e.g., implants and ceramic materials); and Biophysics, investigating the molecular arrangement of proteins and lipids within biological membranes. The system enables scientific activities including detailed analysis of samples from environmental and geologic settings coupled with the ability to characterize mineral assemblages at varying temperature and atmospheric conditions to probe mineral reactivity. Nanomaterials characterization via both high resolution XRD and small-angle X-ray scattering is greatly enhanced, with added ability to determine pore size, crystallinity, and structural variations key to development of new materials. Assessing the fundamental properties of lipid membranes is also made possible through XRD and small-angle X-ray scattering capabilities that can measure molecular correlations at small length scales to address domain formation, a structural feature considered relevant to functions of biomembranes. In addition to its impact on research, the system enhances educational offerings and student training across disciplines at IUPUI. The instrumentation resides in shared research facility, which expands the user base to other academic investigators and local industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This report summarizes how the NSF MRI-1429241 grant entitled “Acquisition of an Advanced X-Ray Diffraction System (XRD) to Support Interdisciplinary Research and Education”  has filled a void on the Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis’s (IUPUI) campus by providing advanced material and nanoscale structural analysis capabilities. These new capabilities have significantly enhanced IUPUI’s major goals of: 1) advancing natural materials, nanotechnology, and biophysical research initiatives and creating new avenues for collaborative research; 2) enhancing educational/professional development and student training; and 3) promoting STEM interest among K-12 students through community outreach activities on campus and throughout Indiana.

This award was used to replace an over 20 year old XRD system that was no longer supported by the manufacturer and that no longer met the needs of a growing multidisciplinary body of researchers with projects spanning: advanced energy storage and conversion system design, investigation of mineral-microbe interactions in modern and ancient settings, defining mineral composition details and reactivity in environmental/geologic systems, biomaterial interactions between proteins and lipids in biological membranes, and more. After careful consideration and exhaustive research by the selection team the Bruker D8 Discover was identified as the XRD System that could best meet the needs of researchers across campus and throughout the region.

The XRD facility was officially open to researchers in August of 2015. Since this time, the XRD has become a staple instrument with continuously  growing user base. Currently, there are 41 trained researchers actively using the instrument, which include faculty, postdoctoral researchers, and students. These users span departments of Earth Science, Chemistry, Physics, Engineering, and Dentistry. The XRD has not only become a crucial tool in their current research endeavors, but has also facilitated new research efforts. Importantly, aside from internal researchers, the XRD’s placement within IUPUI’s Integrated Nanosystems Development Institute’s shared nanoscale characterization facility has provided access to many external university researchers as well. As the number of researchers continues to grow, usage has been quite significant with some periods seeing almost 24-hour a day usage. This shows the instrument has successfully transitioned from a phase of learning and training into heavy research and use. Researchers have begun to disseminate products obtained using the instrument. In a little over a year, XRD data have already been used in 16 publications, 9 conference presentations, and 4 theses. In addition, the instrument has not only impacted existing efforts of researchers, but has also led to new research, made possible by the advanced of the capabilities of the instrument. In addition, the XRD also has regular industry users, and the instrument is strengthening IUPUI’s relationship with the private sector.

Aside from research, the XRD is also enhancing students’ educational training and professional development. The XRD has been integrated within both coursework and outreach at IUPUI. Undergraduate and graduate courses that currently utilize the XRD include: Minerology, Earth Materials, Geochemistry, and Nanosystems Principles. Within these courses the instrument has impacted student training by providing hands on demonstrations and experiments that reinforce materials discussed in class. These course demonstrations also showcase high-end instrumentation and capabilities, thereby building interest in academic research. It is also important to note that many students, both graduate and undergraduates, are trained to use the instrument independently.  

In addition, the XRD has aided in our goal of promoting STEM interest among K-12 students through community outreach activities. The XRD is utilized throughout IUPUI’s expansive NSF-funded outreach efforts, which include REU, RET, and ITEST-sites dedicated to nanomaterials design and characterization. Selected REU and RET participants have been trained to use the XRD in support of their research, and with respect to ITEST, the instrument has been utilized in hands-on demonstrations. The ITEST program has impacted over 60 high school students and 20 high school teachers in the last two years. Importantly, due to IUPUI’s metropolitan location, these participants were predominately from partnering high needs high school with large populations of traditionally underrepresented students. Exposure to this type of instrumentation builds excitement within these students and encourages higher learning.        

At IUPUI, the Integrated Nanosystems Development Institute works to advance nanotechnology research and education across campus and throughout Indiana. Placement of the XRD within the institute’s shared nanoscale characterization facility has allowed the instrument to impact a significant number of individuals, from internal and external researchers, to local industry, and the community through its integration into outreach efforts. In the duration of this award, a Bruker D8 Discover XRD System has been installed, specialized training has been designed and provided to users, and the instrument has become an integral part of IUPUI’s research, education, and outreach efforts. It is providing sophisticated characterization capabilities and advanced training to scientists, engineers, educators, and students from across campus and throughout the surrounding region.
